articles.headline: G.E. Earnings Drop, Raising Broader Fears
articles.snippet: Sharply disappointing results at a company widely viewed as a bellwether underscore the damage done by the credit crisis throughout the economy.
articles.abstract: Sharply disappointing results at a company widely viewed as a bellwether underscore the damage done by the credit crisis throughout the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Electric, which is widely viewed as a bellwether for the economy because of its diverse operations, stunned Wall Street on Friday by reporting sharply disappointing results for the first quarter and creating widespread concern about the outlook for other companies.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Louise Story

articles.headline: Perfectly Legal Immigrants, Until They Applied for Citizenship
articles.snippet: A growing group of legal immigrants who seek citizenship are running afoul of highly technical statutes and being threatened with expulsion.
articles.abstract: A growing group of legal immigrants who seek citizenship are running afoul of highly technical statutes and being threatened with expulsion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SELINSGROVE, Pa.  Dr. Pedro Servano always believed that his journey from his native Philippines to the life of a community doctor in Pennsylvania would lead to American citizenship.

articles.headline: Charities Seek Donors to Replace Wall Street
articles.snippet: Charities that benefit from the largess of Wall Street, law firms and corporations have begun defensive planning.
articles.abstract: Charities that benefit from the largess of Wall Street, law firms and corporations have begun defensive planning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bring on the worry beads.

articles.headline: Fewer Options Open to Pay for Costs of College
articles.snippet: Student loan companies are in turmoil and banks are tightening their standards and raising rates, making it harder for families to use multiple financing sources.
articles.abstract: Student loan companies are in turmoil and banks are tightening their standards and raising rates, making it harder for families to use multiple financing sources.
articles.lead_paragraph: Parents will have to navigate unfamiliar and difficult terrain when it comes time to pay for college this year, with student loan companies in turmoil and banks tightening their standards and raising rates on other types of borrowing.

articles.headline: Aging Jet Fleets an Added Strain on U.S. Airlines
articles.snippet: As airlines have been too financially squeezed to buy new airplanes, they are facing large repair bills and increased scrutiny for the old ones they have kept.
articles.abstract: As airlines have been too financially squeezed to buy new airplanes, they are facing large repair bills and increased scrutiny for the old ones they have kept.
articles.lead_paragraph: An aging fleet is catching up with domestic airlines, and the maintenance issues that inevitably arise are likely to worsen as the industry’s jets grow older and its finances weaken.

articles.headline: Sure It’s Frustrating and Expensive, but Travelers Just Have to Travel
articles.snippet: Despite the many flight cancellations in recent days, the slowing economy, rising gas prices and the weak dollar, the number of air travelers is holding steady so far this year.
articles.abstract: Despite the many flight cancellations in recent days, the slowing economy, rising gas prices and the weak dollar, the number of air travelers is holding steady so far this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nina Rubin, who is in public relations in Atlanta, is going back to the Berkshires this summer but is hoping to save money on her plane ticket by flying into a smaller airport. Sandy Clark, stuck in Chicago when American Airlines canceled her flight, is still planning to fly to Providence, R.I., for her vacation.

articles.headline: China Tries to Solve Its Brand X Blues
articles.snippet: Even as the West fears Chinese manufacturing, China fears Western brands and marketing.
articles.abstract: Even as the West fears Chinese manufacturing, China fears Western brands and marketing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING

articles.headline: A Lender Failed. Did Its Auditor?
articles.snippet: As homeowners and federal investigators pick through the subprime wreckage, many have asked how effectively front-line financial monitors carried out their duties.
articles.abstract: As homeowners and federal investigators pick through the subprime wreckage, many have asked how effectively front-line financial monitors carried out their duties.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH he had been with the mortgage lender New Century Financial for only two months, Tajvinder S. Bindra had spent a good part of late 2006 and early 2007 pelting the company’s controller and a member of its auditing firm, KPMG, with questions about the company’s accounting.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: You Thought You Had an Equity Line
articles.snippet: Lending institutions and mortgage originators got us into this credit mess, but consumers and taxpayers will shoulder most of the costs.
articles.abstract: Lending institutions and mortgage originators got us into this credit mess, but consumers and taxpayers will shoulder most of the costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT was the nation’s lending institutions and mortgage originators that got us into this credit mess, but it is consumers, taxpayers and those companies’ shareholders who will end up shouldering most of the costs.

articles.headline: It’s a Long, Cold, Cashless Siege
articles.snippet: Two months ago — when the cash-out window of the $330 billion auction-rate securities market slammed shut — warning signs flashed across the radar screens of investors.
articles.abstract: Two months ago — when the cash-out window of the $330 billion auction-rate securities market slammed shut — warning signs flashed across the radar screens of investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: CRAIG JOFFE, an investor who owns a laser surgery business in Minneapolis, says that a couple of years ago he was looking for a safe place to put most of his life savings. So he said that on the advice of his broker, he invested 90 percent of his wealth in something he thought was just as conservative, reliable and liquid as cash: three auction-rate securities.

articles.headline: Hard-Liner With Soft Touch Reaches Out to U.S. Flock
articles.snippet: Pope Benedict XVI is known as a man of doctrinal hardness, but his manner is mild and humble.
articles.abstract: Pope Benedict XVI is known as a man of doctrinal hardness, but his manner is mild and humble.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME  Americans often tuck their leaders into tidy boxes of conservative or liberal, charismatic or dull, nice or not. When Pope Benedict XVI arrives on Tuesday to visit America and its church, the overall experience may be one of watching easy categories melt away.
articles.byline: By Ian Fisher and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: On the Defensive, Obama Calls His Words Ill-Chosen
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama fought back against accusations from his rivals that he misunderstands small-town values.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama fought back against accusations from his rivals that he misunderstands small-town values.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama fought back Saturday against accusations from his rivals that he had displayed a profound misunderstanding of small-town values, in a flare-up that left him on the defensive before a series of primaries that could test his ability to win over white voters in economically distressed communities.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Behind Air Chaos, an F.A.A. Pendulum Swing
articles.snippet: A current safety crackdown is a shift away from what critics say was the agency’s coddling of the airlines.
articles.abstract: A current safety crackdown is a shift away from what critics say was the agency’s coddling of the airlines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For all the headaches of flying in the United States, the domestic airlines were until recently considered a logistical marvel, moving two million people a day with remarkably few accidents.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Secret Iraqi Deal Shows Problems in Arms Orders
articles.snippet: Iraq’s military received shoddy equipment under an $833 million deal with Serbia that sidestepped anticorruption safeguards, U.S. commanders said.
articles.abstract: Iraq’s military received shoddy equipment under an $833 million deal with Serbia that sidestepped anticorruption safeguards, U.S. commanders said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  An $833 million Iraqi arms deal secretly negotiated with Serbia has underscored Iraq’s continuing problems equipping its armed forces, a process that has long been plagued by corruption and inefficiency.

articles.headline: ‘Steady Hand’ for the G.O.P. Guides McCain on a New Path
articles.snippet: Charlie Black is easing Senator John McCain into his new role as standard-bearer for the party with which he has often clashed.
articles.abstract: Charlie Black is easing Senator John McCain into his new role as standard-bearer for the party with which he has often clashed.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Senator John McCain’s campaign was collapsing last summer, it was Charlie Black who set the comeback strategy: Mr. McCain had to win New Hampshire.

articles.headline: Apollo Struggles to Keep Debt From Sinking Linens ’n Things
articles.snippet: A bankruptcy filing would be one of the largest since the economy began to weaken and could presage a long-awaited shake-up among companies bought by private equity firms in the last three years.
articles.abstract: A bankruptcy filing would be one of the largest since the economy began to weaken and could presage a long-awaited shake-up among companies bought by private equity firms in the last three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, when times were good, Leon D. Black spent $1.3 billion to buy Linens ’n Things, the home-furnishings chain.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Housing Woes in U.S. Spread Around Globe
articles.snippet: From Ireland to India, housing markets that soared over the last decade are falling back to earth.
articles.abstract: From Ireland to India, housing markets that soared over the last decade are falling back to earth.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The collapse of the housing bubble in the United States is mutating into a global phenomenon, with real estate prices swooning from the Irish countryside and the Spanish coast to Baltic seaports and even parts of northern India.

articles.headline: Dirty Job, but Someone Has to Do It
articles.snippet: The Smoking Gun, the Web site that specializes in ferreting out embarrassing legal documents, is a happy byproduct of the digital revolution.
articles.abstract: The Smoking Gun, the Web site that specializes in ferreting out embarrassing legal documents, is a happy byproduct of the digital revolution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Go to a nondescript office building on the East side of Manhattan, down the hall to a door already in the clutches of a fake dismembered hand, and you will find the newsroom of The Smoking Gun. The take-no-prisoners Web site at thesmokinggun.com is in the midst of spilling affidavits in a Texas polygamy case and recently pushed The Los Angeles Times to retract a major article about the shooting of Tupac Shakur by pointing out that it was based on fake documents.

articles.headline: A City Where You Can’t Hear Yourself Scream
articles.snippet: Noise — outrageous, unceasing, pounding noise — is the backdrop to a tense time in Egypt, prompting protests.
articles.abstract: Noise — outrageous, unceasing, pounding noise — is the backdrop to a tense time in Egypt, prompting protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Egyptians in this capital city say it is harder and harder to be heard and to have a voice, but they are not talking politics. Well, not only politics.

articles.headline: He Wrote 200,000 Books (but Computers Did Some of the Work)
articles.snippet: A professor has developed computer algorithms that collect publicly available information on a given subject, turn them into books, printed on demand or delivered digitally.
articles.abstract: A professor has developed computer algorithms that collect publicly available information on a given subject, turn them into books, printed on demand or delivered digitally.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to write a book. First you have to pick a title. And then there is the table of contents. If you want the book to be categorized, either by a bookseller or a library, it has to be assigned a unique numerical code, like an ISBN, for International Standard Book Number. There have to be proper margins. Finally, there’s the back cover.

articles.headline: Uncertain Church Awaits Pope in U.S.
articles.snippet: Pope Benedict XVI will find that many Catholics are looking for acknowledgment that their church is going through a time of pain.
articles.abstract: Pope Benedict XVI will find that many Catholics are looking for acknowledgment that their church is going through a time of pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks ago, as final preparations were being made for the visit of Pope Benedict XVI to the United States, the bishop of Camden, N.J., announced plans to close or merge nearly half the parishes in his diocese. Meanwhile, Catholics in New Orleans, Boston, New York, Toledo, Ohio, and nearly three dozen other dioceses are mourning the loss of parishes and parochial schools they grew up in.

articles.headline: Co-Payments Soar for Drugs With High Prices
articles.snippet: Health insurance companies are now asking patients to pay more for prescriptions that may save their lives.
articles.abstract: Health insurance companies are now asking patients to pay more for prescriptions that may save their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Health insurance companies are rapidly adopting a new pricing system for very expensive drugs, asking patients to pay hundreds and even thousands of dollars for prescriptions for medications that may save their lives or slow the progress of serious diseases.

articles.headline: At CBS, Bad News Doesn’t End at 7
articles.snippet: No new hit has emerged this year in the network’s prime-time schedule, which makes CBS likely to lose the crown of most-watched network to the Fox network.
articles.abstract: No new hit has emerged this year in the network’s prime-time schedule, which makes CBS likely to lose the crown of most-watched network to the Fox network.
articles.lead_paragraph: Katie Couric may be the least of Leslie Moonves’s worries.

articles.headline: Tibet Backers Show China Value of P.R.
articles.snippet: With the Olympics in mind, China has been exploring American-style public relations approaches.
articles.abstract: With the Olympics in mind, China has been exploring American-style public relations approaches.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon after China was awarded the Olympic Games seven years ago, a series of public relations strategy sessions were held. But it wasn’t the Chinese government holding the sessions: it was grass-roots Tibet support groups in the United States and abroad.

articles.headline: Airline Says Fleet Is Back in Service
articles.snippet: American Airlines said that its fleet of 300 MD-80 jets was back to full strength, after the cancellation of about 3,300 flights last week.
articles.abstract: American Airlines said that its fleet of 300 MD-80 jets was back to full strength, after the cancellation of about 3,300 flights last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: American Airlines said that its fleet of 300 MD-80 jetliners was back to full strength on Sunday, after the cancellation of about 3,300 flights last week.

articles.headline: Union Killings Peril Trade Pact With Colombia
articles.snippet: A surge in killings of labor union members in Colombia is emerging as an issue in the battle over a trade deal.
articles.abstract: A surge in killings of labor union members in Colombia is emerging as an issue in the battle over a trade deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia  Lucy Gómez still shudders when speaking of the murder of her brother, Leonidas, a union leader and bank employee who was beaten and stabbed to death here last month. His murder was part of a recent increase in killings of union members in Colombia, with 17 already this year.
